author: Caesar, Gaius Julius
Title: C. Julii des ersten Roe. keysers warhafftige beschreibunge aller namhafften fuertrefflichen kriege so ihre Keyserliche Majestet wider die Frantzogen, Teutschen, Engellaender, Roemer und andere frembde oder einheimische voelcker in und ausserhalb welschem lande geffuert und auch selbs
Imprint: Frankfurt am Main, [durch Peter Schmidt in verlegung Sigmund Feyerabend vnd Simon HÃ¼ter], 1565
Publisher(s): Peter Schmidt, Simon Hüter, Sigmund Feyerabend
Paratexts (especially noteworthy!): title page illustration [Caesar's assassination in 16th century costume] / Hartmann Schopper's verses to the clergyman Johannes Egolf von Knöringen / Sigmund Feyerabend's prefatory remarks to von Knöringen / illustration [Caesar as 16th century magnate] with verses / Plutarch's life of Caesar in German, with additional illustrations / Lucianic dialogue comparing Scipio, Hannibal, Alexander and Caesar [in German] / essay on the nature of history / short table of names and modern equivalents / text of Gallic commentaries including title and closing illustrations to each book, titles to each chapter and additional [but often repeated] illustrations / preface to civil war commentaries / text of 3 civil war commentaries including title and closing illustrations to each book , chapter headings and additional illustrations / epitome of Alexandrian and Spanish war commentaries / printer's emblem giving date of 1565
Notes: last 3 books of CW commentaries are epitomized

author: Caesar, Gaius Julius

Imprint: Frankfurt am Main, [durch Peter Schmidt]in verlegung Sigmund Feyerabend, 1588
Paratexts (especially noteworthy!): title page illustration [Caesar's assassination in 16th century costume] / Sigmund Feyerabend's prefatory letter to ?Max Rehlinger, lord of Kleinkitzighofen in Bavaria / brief history of Rome from Ammianus Marcellinus / annotated list of 'all Roman Keysers' [100s of pages!!] / illustration [Caesar as 16th century magnate] with verses / Plutarch's life of Caesar in German, with additional illustrations / Lucianic dialogue comparing Scipio, Hannibal, Alexander and Caesar [in German] / essay on the nature of history / short table of names and modern equivalents Lucianic dialogue comparing Scipio, Hannibal, Alexander and Caesar [in German] / essay on the nature of history / short table of names and modern equivalents / text of Gallic commentaries including title and closing illustrations to each book, titles to each chapter and additional [but often repeated] illustrations / preface to civil war commentaries / text of 3 civil war commentaries including title and closing illustrations to each book , chapter headings and additional illustrations / epitome of Alexandrian and Spanish war commentaries / list of contents / printer's emblem giving date of 1566
Notes: last 3 books of CW commentaries are epitomized

signatures: Ã£6 ~e6 ~i6 Ãµ6 ~u4 a-o6 p4 q-z6 aa-dd6 ee8 ff-gg6 hh4-ii4; AA-EE6 FF4 GG-II6 KK10 LL-PP6 QQ8 RR-SS6
Contents: Volume 1: 'Preambule'; medallion of Caesar as 'Dictator Perpetuus' and citing his 'parricide' from Val. Max.; praises of Caesar and Pompey from Pliny, Nat. Hist. 7.25 ; license of royal privilege ; Eutropius, summary of Caesar's deeds, 'extracted from Suetonius's memoirs'; Florus's epitomes of Livy's 11th and 12th decades dealing with Caesar ; summary of Caesar's life [early modern] ; 'to the readers' ; map of France [not very useful]; text of Gallic commentaries, each book preceded by arguments and contents ; Annotations of de Vigenere, including battle diagrams ; table of significant persons in the commentaries ; table of French and Latin names ; the same table with French names first ; table of principal matters in the text and annotations. Volume 2: extract of Florus IV ; brief summary of the 'motifs et occasions' of the war ; text of civil war commentaries, each book preceded by argument and chapters ; 'Annotations' of de Vigenere [very lengthy] ; alphabetical table of places, with lengthy descriptions ; chronology of Caesar's career, 56 BC to 42 BC ; notice ad signature of Blaise de la Vigenere, remarking on the end of his labours in his 68th year, 1589

author: Caesar, Gaius Julius
Title: Observations upon the five first bookes of Caesars commentaries setting fourth the practise of the art military in the time of the Roman Empire: wherein are handled all the chiefest point of their discipline, with the true reason of every part, together with such instructions as may be drawn from their proceedings, for the better direction of our moderne warres
Contents: Dedication to Sir Francis Vere ; 'To the Reader' ; essay defending 'reading and discourse' as well as experience to 'make a soldier perfect in the art military'; text up to V.44 then summary (in chapter 'xx') of remainder of book V, incl. arguments to each book and 'observations' after each ''chapter', accompanied by sumptuous (original?) battle diagrams.
Notes: This text has many variations in the print run

author: Plutarchus

Additional Notes: Checked online copy. Book 4 (of 4) is a partial translation of Plutarch's Demetrius: 'Cy commence la quatriesme liure extraict de Plutharque en la vie de Demetrius.' I haven't specifically checked but it must include most of Plutarch's Life, given its length. Seyssel did not know Latin and worked from a lost MS translation of Janus Lascaris: Boone, Rebecca. “Claude de Seyssel’s Translations of Ancient Historians.” Journal of the History of Ideas 61, no. 4 (2000): 561–75. https://doi.org/10.2307/3654069 (565-66).

Contents: De cohibenda ira ; De invidia et odio ; De tranquillitate animi
Additional Notes: Checked in BL. USTC includes the next item in the Sammelband (De tranquillitate animi) as part of this edition, but it looks more likely that the two are bibliographically separate entities. The one thing that makes me hesitate is that the Greek text of De tranquillitate starts on A1r (which is unusual if preceded just by a title-page with blank verso) and the text of De invidia et odio ends on delta7v; there is a leaf bound between that the end of De invidia et odio and the title-page of De tranquillitate but that may have been inserted later.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Guter sitten einund zwentzig buecher.
Contents: Praecepta gerendae reipublicae ; Ad principem ineruditum ; Maxime cum principibus philosopho esse disserendum ; De cohibenda ira ; Quomodo adulator ab amico internoscatur ; De capienda ex inimicis utilitate ; De curiositate ; Coniugalia praecepta ; De liberis educandis ; Mulierum virtutes ; De tuenda sanitate praecepta ; Animine an corporis affectiones sint peiores ; De virtute et vitio ; De invidia et odio ; De cupiditate divitiarum ; De vitando aere alieno ; De amicorum multitudine ; An recte dictum sit latenter esse vivendum ; De tranquillitate animi ; Quaestionum convivalium ; De sera numinis vindicta
Paratexts (especially noteworthy!): Includes summaries at the start of each treatise.
Additional Notes: Copy inspected at HAB. The same book as USTC 709338 and 699783, apparently, but with a different title-page, preliminaries, and date (and, in the case of 699783 additional content). 699783 has 1535 in the colophon, as apparently does 709338 (which I haven't seen, but that's what USTC says). So what seems to have happened here is that Schott tried to sell unsold copies of the first edition by adding a new t-p and, in 1551, new content, not once, but twice. In 1544 (apparently from the number of pages: not seen) and again in 1551 he then adds what appears to be a translation of Erasmus's Apophthegmata (of which the first couple of books are indeed from Plutarch) by Heinrich Eppendorf. For reasons unknown to me, the name of the translator is removed not just from the title-page but also from the dedication in 699783 (and presumably 709338). It seems pretty clear that Herr is translating from the Latin, given that he starts with Plutarch's apocryphal letter to Trajan, which does not exist in the Greek. I'VE NOT ADDED THE TRANSLATORS OF THE LATIN VERSIONS ON WHICH HERR IS EVIDENTLY BASING HIS TRANSLATION.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Le livre de l'education et nourriture des enfans
Additional Notes: Inspected copy in HAB. Intermediate translator from Aulotte, but the privilege (A1v) notes that it was translated from the Latin. Dedication to Madame Antoinette de Boubon; summary preceding treatise; and interesting index at the end, which describes each entry in detail ('Aeschines', 'Alexandre de grand', 'Adolescence') and is as long as the work itself (as indicated by the full title: 'Livre de Plutarque de l'éducation et nourriture des enfants, traduit de latin en français par J. Collin, licencié ès loixs demeurant à Châlons en Champagne, auquel est ajoutée une table selon lordre de l'alphabet, contenant la déclaration de plusieurs dictions, histoires et fables pour plus facile intelligence du livre'). Omits the section on pederasty, just as the English translation by Elyot had.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Paidagogos
Additional Notes: Checked in BL (photographic reproduction without title-page). Francesca Lotti writes: 'la  traduzione  in  greco  moderno  del  trattatello pseudoplutarcheo De liberis educandis, pubblicato in Venezia il 2 gennaio 1544 per  i  tipi  di Bartolomeo  Zanetti  con  il  titolo  di Paidagogos  e  corredato  da  una lettera dedicatoria indirizzata al vescovo Dionisio Zanettini, detto ‘Grechetto’ per le sue origini cretesi. In questa epistola Sofianos cita gli amici residenti a Venezia, che  avevano  sostenuto  il  suo  progetto:  tra  i  più  noti,  oltre  ai  corfioti  Eparchos, Devaris  e  Trivolis,  ci  sono  Antonio  Kalliergis,  letterato  cretese  nominato  da Giraldi  Cinzio  nei  suoi Dialoghi,  Michele  Lestarchos  di  Zante,  il  conte  Giorgio Corinzio, nipote di Arsenios Apostolos e collaboratore di Paolo Manuzio. Tra tutti questi nomi appare anche quello di Angelo Forte, chiamato «nuovo Ippocrate» ed elogiato per le sue conoscenze in campo medico.' (PhD thesis, Pisa, 2014) <https://etd.adm.unipi.it/theses/available/etd-10222014-181953/>.

Publisher(s): Pierre Gaultier | Jean Barbé | Claude Garamond
Additional Notes: Inspected copy in HAB (misdated 1595). Book 4 (of 4) is a partial translation of Plutarch's Demetrius: 'Cy commence la quatriesme liure extraict de Plutharque en la vie de Demetrius.' I haven't specifically checked but it must include most of Plutarch's Life, given its length. Seyssel did not know Latin and worked from a lost MS translation of Janus Lascaris: Boone, Rebecca. “Claude de Seyssel’s Translations of Ancient Historians.” Journal of the History of Ideas 61, no. 4 (2000): 561–75. https://doi.org/10.2307/3654069 (565-66).

Title: Moralium exemplorum libri novem, summa diligentia castigati, ac fidelissimis eruditissimorum virorum Oliuerii f. Arziganensis, Iodociique Badii Ascensii commentariis enarrati. Quibus addita sunt quatuor & viginti exempla, nuper Aldi Manutii industria inventa, eiusdem Ascensii commentariis exornata. Cum duplici indice, altero quidem capitum, altero vero eorum, quae toto opere notatu digna visa sunt. Insunt praeterea Theophili viri eruditissimi perutiles lucubrationes, quae tibi non mediocrierunt (si huius autoris virtutes optime nosse uolueris) adiumento. Adiunctis etiam autoritatibus Livii, Iustini, Plutarchi, Dyonisii, et multorum aliorum illustrium historiographorum, quae in aliis deerant

author: Plutarchus
Title: Peri paidōn agōgēs. De liberorum institutione
Additional Notes: Not seen. BP lists two editions of De liberis educandis by Wechel in 1550, one in Greek (BP16_114152) and one in Guarino's Latin translation (BP16_114150). It's impossible to determine what the entry in USTC refers to, since no surviving copy or detailed title information is given. It lists the language as Greek, but the languages in USTC are highly unreliable. Given the extent of the volume (28 leaves or 56 pages in quarto), I'm going to guess that it's referring to both: the Latin copy in the Bibliothèque de Genève is just 31 pages.

Title: Moralium exemplorum libri novem summa diligentia castigati, ac fidelissimis eruditissimorum uirorum Oliverii f. Arziganensis, Iodocique Badii Ascensii commentariis enarrati, quibus addita sunt quatuor & viginti exempla, nuper Aldi Manutiiindustria inventa, eiusdem Ascensii commentariis exornata. Cum duplici indice, altero quidem capitum, altero vero eorum, quae toto opere notatu digna uisa sunt. Insunt praeterea Theophili viri eruditisimi perutiles lucubrationes, quae tibi non mediocri erunt (si huius autoris virtutes optime nosse uolueris) adiumento. Adiunctis etiam autoritatibus Livii, Iustini, Plutarchi, Dionysii, & multorum aliorum illustrium historiographorum quae in aliis deerant

Title: La prima [-seconda] parte delle vite di Plutarco. Tradotte da m. Lodovico Domenichi, con gli suoi sommarii posti dinanzi a ciascuna vita. Con due tavole, le quali sono poste in fine della seconda parte: l'una serue alle cose notabili, nell'altra si sonoraccolti ordinariamente tutti i nomi antichi e moderni di diversi paesi, città, mari, promontori, venti, fiumi, monti e luoghi che in tutta l'opera si contengono. Con la dichiaratione de i pesi e delle monete, che si usavano dagli antici
Imprint: Venezia, appresso Gabriele Giolito De Ferrari, 1559
Contents: VOL 1 ; Theseus ; Romulus ; Comparison ; Lycurgus ; Numa ; Comparison ; Solon ; Publicola ; Comparison ; Alcibiades ; Coriolanus ; Comparison ; Themistocles ; Camillus ; Pericles ; Fabius Maximus ; Comparison ; Pelopidas ; Marcellus ; Comparison ; Hannibal ; Scipio ; Comparison ; Philopoemen ; Flamininus ; Comparison ; Aristides ; Cato the Elder ; Comparison ; Aemilius Paulus ; Timoleon ; Comparison ; Agis and Cleomenes ; Tiberius and Caius Gracchus ; Comparison ; Lysander ; Sulla ; Comparison ; Pyrrhus ; Caius Marius ; Eumenes ; Sertorius ; Comparison ; Cimon ; Lucullus ; Comparison ; Nicias ; Crassus ; Comparison ; Agesilaus ; Pompey ; Comparison ; VOL. 2 ; Alexander ; Julius Caesar ; Phocion ; Cato the Younger ; Dion ; Brutus ; Comparison ; Demosthenes ; Cicero ; Comparison ; Demetrius ; Antony ; Comparison ; Artaxerxes ; Aratus ; Galba ; Otho ; Homer ; Evagoras ; Atticus ; Plato ; Aristoteles ; Carolus Magnus

Title: Le vite de gli huomini illustri greci et romani di Plutarco Cheroneo, sommo filosofo et historico, tradotte nuovamente da m. Francesco Sansouino. Con le tavole copiosissime delle cose notabili che si contengono nella prima & seconda parte, poste nel fine. Con sommarii et utili postille, che dichiarano i luoghi oscuri de' testi per via di discorsi. Con una tavola di monti, di città di isole, di fiumi, & di mari nella quale si dichiarano i nomi antichi co' moderni, come si puo vedere nel fin delle tavole.Et con le figure de capitani & de re de quali si tratta, poste in disegno et cavate dalle medaglie antiche

author: Plutarchus
Title: Apoftemmi, motti arguti piacevoli, e sentenze notabili, cosi di principi come di filosofi
Imprint: Venezia, appresso Gabriele Giolito De Ferrari, 1565
Contents: Regum et imperatorum apophthegmata ; Apophthegmata Laconica
Additional Notes: La raccolta del G., anche se è presentata come versione da Plutarco, in realtà "non è che una traduzione integrale degli apoftegmi di Erasmo": con una diversa disposizione della materia e con la sola aggiunta degli apoftegmi di Cosimo de' Medici alla fine dell'opera, l'operazione è tale che "se per un lato dissimula nel titolo e nell'ordine questa filiazione, per l'altro essa vien quasi ostentata nella fedeltà e nell'integrità della traduzione" (P. Cherchi, Polimatia di riuso. Mezzo secolo di plagio (1539-1589), Roma 1998)' (https://en.maremagnum.com/rare-books/apoftemmi-di-plutarco-motti-arguti-piacevoli-e-sentenze/136679748).

author: Plutarchus
Other Authors: Valerius Maximus ; Oliviero d'Arzignano ; Manuzio, Aldo ; Livius, Titus ; Justinus, Marcus Junianus ; Dionysius Halicarnassensis ; Chalcondylas, Theophilus ; Bade, Josse
Title: Factorum, et dictorum memorabilium libri novem. Fidelissimis eruditissimorum virorum Oliuerii, scilicet Arziganensis, Iodocique Badii Ascensii commentariis enarrati, quibus addita sunt quattuor & viginti exempla, nuper Aldi Manutii industria inventa, eiusdemque Ascensii commentariis exornata. Cum duplici indice  Insunt praeterea Theophili viri eruditissimi perutiles lucubrationes, quae tibi non mediocri erunt ad huius auctoris virtutes optime noscendas adiumento. Adiunctis etiam auctoritatibus Dionysii, Livii, Iustini, Plutarchi, et multorum illustrium historiographorum, quae in aliis deerant. Quae omnia recenti hac nostra editione diligentissime expolita sunt, accuratissimeque elaborata
Imprint: Venezia, apud Giovanni Maria I Bonelli, 1565

Additional Notes: This is wrongly dated to 1560 in USTC, before the book was published in 1564. The entry in the Lyon library catalogue shows this is, in fact, from 1566. 'héritiers Sébastien Gryphe' seems to derive from the fact that it just has the Gryphe symbol on the t-p, but other catalogue entries in Worldcat make it sufficiently clear that this was printed by Antoine. This must refer to volume 2 (though the pages aren't indicated so can't be sure) because Lyon has 2 vols and USTC 139658 (=vol. 1) also lists a copy in Lyon.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Πλουταρχου Χαιρονέωσ περὶ ἀρετῆς καὶ κακίας. Plutarchi Chaeronensis de virtute et vitio.
Additional Notes: Checked in BL. Not in USTC. The Latin translation is not Luscinus's and I couldn't find it on Google. It starts 'Vestimenta censentur hominem calfacre, quae sane nec calfaciunt, nec calorem eiaculantur (eorum enim quodque per se frigidum est: vnde etiam saepenumero exaestuantes & febricitantes, pro aliis alia subinde mutant) sed quem ex se calorem effundit homo, eum vestis admota corpori, continet & coercet atque corpore conclusum dispergi rursum non sinit.' It ends 'exhilarabit te rerum copia multos beneficiis afficientem, paupertas de multis non sollicitum, gloria honoratum, & gloriae contemptus non inuisum.'

Imprint: Venezia, appresso Gabriele Giolito De Ferrari, 1566
Contents: Regum et imperatorum apophthegmata ; Apophthegmata Laconica
Additional Notes: Inspected copy in HAB. 'La raccolta del G., anche se è presentata come versione da Plutarco, in realtà "non è che una traduzione integrale degli apoftegmi di Erasmo": con una diversa disposizione della materia e con la sola aggiunta degli apoftegmi di Cosimo de' Medici alla fine dell'opera, l'operazione è tale che "se per un lato dissimula nel titolo e nell'ordine questa filiazione, per l'altro essa vien quasi ostentata nella fedeltà e nell'integrità della traduzione" (P. Cherchi, Polimatia di riuso. Mezzo secolo di plagio (1539-1589), Roma 1998)' (https://en.maremagnum.com/rare-books/apoftemmi-di-plutarco-motti-arguti-piacevoli-e-sentenze/136679748).

author: Plutarchus
Title: L'histoire traictant des successeurs d'Alexandre le Grand
Additional Notes: Not attributed to Plutarch in USTC, which is odd because all earlier French translation and later English and Italian translations are. Book 4 (of 4) is a partial translation of Plutarch's Demetrius: 'Cy commence la quatriesme liure extraict de Plutharque en la vie de Demetrius.' I haven't specifically checked but it must include most of Plutarch's Life, given its length. Seyssel did not know Latin and worked from a lost MS translation of Janus Lascaris: Boone, Rebecca. “Claude de Seyssel’s Translations of Ancient Historians.” Journal of the History of Ideas 61, no. 4 (2000): 561–75. https://doi.org/10.2307/3654069 (565-66).

author: Plutarchus
Title: A righte noble and pleasant history of the successors of Alexander surnamed the Great
Imprint: London, Henry Bynneman for Humphrey Toy, 1569
Additional Notes: Based on my edition, and see Lathrop, p. 195. Book 4 (of 4) is a partial translation of Plutarch's Demetrius: 'Cy commence la quatriesme liure extraict de Plutharque en la vie de Demetrius.' I haven't specifically checked but it must include most of Plutarch's Life, given its length. Seyssel did not know Latin and worked from a lost MS translation of Janus Lascaris: Boone, Rebecca. “Claude de Seyssel’s Translations of Ancient Historians.” Journal of the History of Ideas 61, no. 4 (2000): 561–75. https://doi.org/10.2307/3654069 (565-66).

The inclusion of Homer ; Evagoras ; Atticus ; Plato ; Aristoteles ; Carolus Magnus makes it all but certain that this is based on the Latin edition, which as early as 1491 (and perhaps even earlier), included these lives, including Isengrin's mid-century Basel editions, in the same order.

(but not Cons. ad Ux.) is indebted to the Latin (of Carlo Valgulio) but is mainly translated from the Greek. Not included in data we got from USTC but now attributed to Plutarch in 1571 and 1572 but not 1600 edition.

Title: Problemata Aristotelis ac philosophorum medicorumque complurium, ad varias quaestiones cognoscendas admodum digna et ad naturalem philosophiam discutiendam maxime spectantia
Imprint: Lyon, excudebat Jean Marcorelle ex officina Louis Cloquemin [et] Etienne Michel, 1573
Publisher(s): Jean Marcorelle | Louis Cloquemin | Etienne Michel
Additional Notes: Checked online copy. Pp. 285-87, titled 'Addidimvs hvc ex Plvtarchi problematis selectiora quaedam' (=Quaest. Rom. 68-71). This and USTC 140909 are problematic inclusions because this brief extract from Quaest. Rom. is, in fact, included in most or all editions of the Problemata Aristotelis, of which there are many, e.g. Frankfurt 1549, Cologne 1555, Lyon 1557, Frankfurt 1558, Cologne 1563, Venice 1568, Venice 1569, Venice 1571. So we either include all of those or - better - exclude these two items.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Peri tēs eis ta engona philostorgias. De amore naturali parentum erga proles
Additional Notes: Checked in BL. Curious item: the BL copy (714.e.22.(2.)), preceded by USTC 116638, comprises both a Greek text and a Latin one of the same treatise, but there is apparently no evidence that the two are bibliographically related. The Latin translation is not noted on the t-p of the Greek and contains no colophon that might correspond to the Greek; the type and appearance are quite different too. The Greek text, curiously, ends on A5v, and there is no evidence of A6, which is where you would expect the Latin translation to start if it was part of the same edition. The Latin text instead starts with a new signature (A1) and new page numbers. The Latin could have been taken from a separate edition, but that begs the question why it starts at A1 (perhaps the preliminaries had a symbol for a signature). ONCE I'VE IDENTIFIED EDITIONS INCLUDING LONGOLIUS'S LATIN TRANSLATION, INVESTIGATE FURTHER (PHOTOS TAKEN OF WHOLE VOLUME).

author: Plutarchus
Title: Van het gheluck ende ongheluck des houwelicks
Additional Notes: Not seen. Not attributed to Plutarch in USTC. Format in USTC corrected on basis of anet.be entry. Aulotte, p. 64 n. 3 states that this includes the Plutarch translation (confirmed by Charles Louis Ruelens and Auguste de Backer, Annales Plantiniennes ... Première partie. Christophe Plantin. 1555-1589 (1865), p. 196) and is based on Marconville's French. Variant of USTC 414925, which has no colophon (anet.be).

author: Plutarchus
Title: Libelli aliquot formandis tum juventutis moribus, tum linguae Graecae, Latinae, Gallicae et Germanicae utilissimi
Additional Notes: Inspected copy in HAB. Parallel text edition in 4 languages. The French translation is by Amyot (as Aulotte notes and GLN15-16 correctly identifies). GLN15-16 also lists Xylander as a translator, though it's not clear whether that is of the Latin, the German, or both. CHECK. The German translation is not the one by Johann Fischart. Daneau is the author of the final work in the volume, Ethica Christiana.

Title: Vite di Plutarco Cheroneo de gli huomini illustri greci et romani. Nuovamente tradotte per m. Lodovico Domenichi & altri. Et diligentemente confrontate co' testi greci per m. Lionardo Ghini per abbellimento e vaghezza delle quali oltr'a' sommarii del Domenichi in questa nostra ultima impressione vi habbiamo inserti gli argomenti et le annotationi del Sansouino con la vita dell'autore descritta da athomaso Porcacchi Parte prima [-seconda]

Title: Vite di Plutarco Cheroneo de gli huomini illustri greci et romani. Nuovamente tradotte per m. Lodovico Domenichi & altri. Et diligentemente confrontate co' testi greci per m. Lionardo Ghini Con la vita dell'auttore descritta da Thomaso Porcacchi. Condue tavole copiosissime: l'una delle cose notabili: et l'altra de' nomi delle città, isole, mari, laghi, fiumi, monti et altri luoghi e paesi illustri. Parte prima [-seconda]

signatures: ¶8 ¶¶6 a-z8 aa-kk8 ll6 mm-zz8 aaa-zzz8 aaaa8 (aaaa8 blank) A-M8 A-D8 (D6-8 blank) *4
Additional Notes: This looks very dodgy. There are clearly a folio (Balsamo-Simonin, Abel L’Angelier, n° 122) and an octavo edition (Balsamo-Simonin, Abel L’Angelier, n° 123), but not two octavo editions. The bibliographical reference to GLN15-16 bizarrely refers to the folio edition (Balsamo-Simonin, Abel L’Angelier, n° 122). CHECK IN Balsamo-Simonin.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Les oeuvres morales
signatures: ã8 **4 A-D8 a-z8 aa-gg8 hh2 (hh2 blank)
Contents: Dedication. Amyot to Charles IX ; Address to reader. Simon Goulart ; Content.  ; I. Comment il fault nourrir les Enfans ; II. Comment il fault lire les Poëtes ; III. Comment il fault ouir ; IV. De la Vertu morale ; V. Du vice & de la vertu ; VI. Que la vertu se peult enseigner ; VII. Comment on pourra discerner le flatteur d'auec l'amy ; VIII. Comment il fault refrener la cholere ; IX. De la Curiosité ; X. De la Tranquillité de l'ame & repos de l'esprit ; XI. De la mauuaise honte ; XII. De l'amitié fraternelle ; XIII. Du trop parler ; XIV. De l'auarice & conuoitise d'auoir ; XV. De l'amour & charité naturelle des peres enuers les enfans ; XVI. De la pluralité d'amis ; XVII. De la Fortune ; XVIII. De l'enuie & de la haine ; XIX. Comment on pourra receuoir vtilité de ses ennemis ; XX. Comment on pourra apperceuoir si lon amende en l'exercice de la vertu ; XXI. De la superstition ; XXII. Du Bannissement ; XXIII. Qu'il ne fault point emprunter à vsure ; XXIV. Qu'il fault qu’vn Philosophe conuerse avec les Princes ; XXV. Qu'il est requis qu'vn Prince soit sçauant ; XXVI. Que le vice est suffisant pour rendre l'homme malheureux ; XXVII. Comment on se peult louer soy mesme sans reprehension ; XXVIII. Quelles passions sont les pires, celles de l'ame, ou celles du corps ; XXIX. Les Preceptes de Mariage ; XXX. Le Banquet des sept Sages ; XXXI. Instruction pour ceulx qui manient affaires d'estat ; XXXII. Si l'homme d'aage se doit mesler d'affaires publicques ; XXXIII. Les dicts notables des anciens Roys, Princes & grands Capitaines ; XXXIV. Les dicts notables des Lacedaemoniens ; XXXV. Les vertueux faicts des femmes ; XXXVI. Consolation enuoyee à Apollonius sur la mort de son fils ; XXXVII. Consolation enuoyee à sa femme, sur la mort de sa fille ; XXXVIII. Pourquoy la Iustice diuine differe quelque fois la punition des malefices ; XXXIX. Que les bestes brutes vsent de la raison ; XL. S'il est loisible de manger chair ; XLI. Que lon ne sçauroit viure ioyeusement selon Epicurus ; XLII. Si ce mot commun est bien dit, Cache ta vie ; XLIII. Les Regles & preceptes de Santé ; XLIV. De la Fortune des Romains * ; XLV. De la Fortune ou vertu d'Alexandre ; XLVI. D'Isis & d'Osiris ; XLVII. Des Oracles qui ont cessé ; XLVIII. Que signifie ce mot Ei ;  Indice Très Ample des noms, sentences et dits notables ;  Sur le reste des oevvres morales de plutarque ; Content page - precedes S.G.S address ; Address to readers. Simon Goulart ; Indices des principales matieres et chose ; I. Les Propos de Tabl ; II. Les Opinions des Philosophe ; III. Les Demandes des choses Romaine ; IV. Les Demandes des choses Grecque ; V. Collation abregee d'aucunes histoire ; VI. Les vies des dix Orateurs. ; VII. De trois fortes de gouuernemen ; VIII. Sommaire de la Comparaison d'Aristophanes & de Menande ; IX. Estranges Accidents aduenus pour l'Amou ; X. Quels Animaux sont les plus aduise ; XI. Si les Atheniens ont esté plus excellents en armes qu'en lettre ; XII. Lequel est plus vtile, le feu, ou l'ea ; XIII. Du premier froi ; XIV. Les Causes naturelle ; XV. Les Questions Platoniques ; XVI. De la creation de l'Am ; XVII. De la fatale Destine ; XVIII. Que les Stoïques disent des choses plus estranges que les Poëte ; XIX. Les contredicts des Philosophes Stoïques ; XX. Des communes Conceptions contre les Stoique ; XXI. Contre l'Epicurien Colote ; XXII. De l'Amou ; XXIII. De la face qui apparoist au rond de la Lun ; XXIV. Pourquoy la prophetisse Pythie ne rend plus les oracles en ver ; XXV. De l'Esprit familier de Socrate ; XXVI. De la malignité d'Herodot ; XXVII. De la Musique

author: Plutarchus
Title: Les oeuvres morales et meslees
Imprint: Paris, Fédéric Morel chez Barthélemy Macé, 1587
signatures: a6 (a6 blank) a-z6 A-Z6 Aa-Zz6 Aaa-Zzz6 Aaaa-Vuuu6 a-n6 o-p4
Additional Notes: Checked in BL. The title-page has Macé's name alone, with a date of 1587; the colophon reads 'Acheué d'imprimer le xxvij du mois d'Auril, M.D.LXXXI, par Federic Morel Imprimeur du Roy'. Detailed comparison of the Morel and Macé's 1581 edition (USTC 53074) alongside this edition in the BL strongly suggests that vol. 1 (like vol. 2), following the preliminaries, is a re-issue of the 1581 edition. Pace USTC, no annotations by Goulart, as this is (based on) an earlier edition.

Title: Vite di Plutarco Cheroneo de gli huomini illustri greci et romani. Nuovamente tradotte per m. Lodovico Domenichi & altri. Et diligentemente confrontate co' testi greci per m. Lionardo Ghini. Per abbellimento e vaghezza delle quali vi habbiamo inseriti gli argomenti et le annotationi del Sansouino: et l'habbiamo adornate di figure tratte dal vivo e dal naturale. Con la vita dell'auttore descritta da Thomaso Porcacchi Parte prima [-seconda]
Contents: VOL 1 ; Theseus ; Romulus ; Comparison ; Lycurgus ; Numa ; Comparison ; Solon ; Publicola ; Comparison ; Alcibiades ; Coriolanus ; Comparison ; Themistocles ; Camillus ; Pericles ; Fabius Maximus ; Comparison ; Pelopidas ; Marcellus ; Comparison ; Hannibal ; Scipio ; Comparison ; Philopoemen ; Flamininus ; Comparison ; Aristides ; Cato the Elder ; Comparison ; Aemilius Paulus ; Timoleon ; Comparison ; Agis and Cleomenes ; Tiberius and Caius Gracchus ; Comparison ; Lysander ; Sulla ; Comparison ; Pyrrhus ; Caius Marius ; Eumenes ; Sertorius ; Comparison ; Cimon ; Lucullus ; Comparison ; Nicias ; Crassus ; Comparison ; Agesilaus ; Pompey ; Comparison ; VOL. 2 ; Alexander ; Julius Caesar ; Phocion ; Cato the Younger ; Dion ; Brutus ; Comparison ; Demosthenes ; Cicero ; Comparison ; Demetrius ; Antony ; Comparison ; Artaxerxes ; Aratus ; Galba ; Otho ; Homer ; Evagoras ; Atticus ; Plato ; Aristoteles  ; Carolus Magnus
Additional Notes: Checked online copy and seen in HAB. The title-page suggests that the summaries and annotations are Sansovino's: these don't appear any different from earlier editions (despite what the t-p suggests) so presumably the same applies to the earlier editions - but given that the summaries and marginal notes appear in 1560, when Sansovino had not been published yet, this does not look to be the case: LOOK FURTHER INTO THIS.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Peri polypragmosynes.
Imprint: Helmstedt, ex officina typographica Jakob Lucius (I), 1590
Additional Notes: Inspected copy at HAB. Has a bit of commentary at the end. Given the similarity of this edition to USTC 684228, attributed to Caselius, and the fact that it was printed in Helmstedt, it seems likely that this too is by Caselius. Tomás Valle writes (13/05/2022): 'You're also right that the 1590 edition is definitely by Caselius. The verso of the title page has a poem and his fancily printed signature, both of which appear on the title page of the 1588 edition. And, the text at the end is clearly an earlier version of the scholia in his 1595 translation of the same work.'

author: Plutarchus
Other Authors: Valerius Maximus ; Oliviero d'Arzignano ; Manuzio, Aldo ; Livius, Titus ; Justinus, Marcus Junianus ; Dionysius Halicarnassensis ; Chalcondylas, Theophilus ; Bade, Josse
Title: Factorum, et dictorum memorabilium libri novem. Fidelissimis eruditissimorum virorum Oliuerji, scilicet Arziganensis, Iodocique Badii Ascensii commentariis enarrati. Quibus addita sunt quattuor et viginti exempla, nuper Aldi Manutii industria inventa; eiusdemque Ascensii commentariis exornata. Insunt praeterea Theophili viri eruditissimi perutiles lucubrationes: quae studiosis non mediocri erunt ad huius auctoris virtutes optime noscendas adiumento. Adiunctis etiam auctoritatibus Dionysii, Livii, Iustini, Plutarchi et multorum aliorum illustrium historiographorum. Quae omnia recentia hac nostra ultima editione diligentissime expolita sunt, accuratissimeque elaborata. Cum duplici indice, altero capitum altero eorum, quae toto opere
Imprint: Venezia, [haer. Melchiorre I Sessa] apud Lorenzo Bertelli, 1590

author: Plutarchus
Title: Oracoli politici cioè sentenze, et documenti nobili, & illustri raccolti da tutti gli antichi, e principali auttori hebrei, greci, & latini, per ornamento e conservatione della vita christiana, & civile. Co i fiori de gli Apoftemmi di Plutarco
Additional Notes: Inspected copy at HAB. Not recorded as by Plutarch in USTC, despite the fact that his name appears on the t-p. I haven't checked where all the material comes from, but the fact that it starts with the letter to Trajan indicates that this is Regum et imperatorum apophthegmata rather than the Spartan sayings; that's also what the BL catalogue says. CHECK AGAIN EARLIER ITALIAN TRANSLATIONS TO SEE IF IT'S TAKEN FROM ANY OF THOSE.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Les oeuvres morales
Contents: Dedication. Amyot to Charles IX ; Address to reader. Simon Goulart ; Content.  ; I. Comment il fault nourrir les Enfans ; II. Comment il fault lire les Poëtes ; III. Comment il fault ouir ; IV. De la Vertu morale ; V. Du vice & de la vertu ; VI. Que la vertu se peult enseigner ; VII. Comment on pourra discerner le flatteur d'auec l'amy ; VIII. Comment il fault refrener la cholere ; IX. De la Curiosité ; X. De la Tranquillité de l'ame & repos de l'esprit ; XI. De la mauuaise honte ; XII. De l'amitié fraternelle ; XIII. Du trop parler ; XIV. De l'auarice & conuoitise d'auoir ; XV. De l'amour & charité naturelle des peres enuers les enfans ; XVI. De la pluralité d'amis ; XVII. De la Fortune ; XVIII. De l'enuie & de la haine ; XIX. Comment on pourra receuoir vtilité de ses ennemis ; XX. Comment on pourra apperceuoir si lon amende en l'exercice de la vertu ; XXI. De la superstition ; XXII. Du Bannissement ; XXIII. Qu'il ne fault point emprunter à vsure ; XXIV. Qu'il fault qu’vn Philosophe conuerse avec les Princes ; XXV. Qu'il est requis qu'vn Prince soit sçauant ; XXVI. Que le vice est suffisant pour rendre l'homme malheureux ; XXVII. Comment on se peult louer soy mesme sans reprehension ; XXVIII. Quelles passions sont les pires, celles de l'ame, ou celles du corps ; XXIX. Les Preceptes de Mariage ; XXX. Le Banquet des sept Sages ; XXXI. Instruction pour ceulx qui manient affaires d'estat ; XXXII. Si l'homme d'aage se doit mesler d'affaires publicques ; XXXIII. Les dicts notables des anciens Roys, Princes & grands Capitaines ; XXXIV. Les dicts notables des Lacedaemoniens ; XXXV. Les vertueux faicts des femmes ; XXXVI. Consolation enuoyee à Apollonius sur la mort de son fils ; XXXVII. Consolation enuoyee à sa femme, sur la mort de sa fille ; XXXVIII. Pourquoy la Iustice diuine differe quelque fois la punition des malefices ; XXXIX. Que les bestes brutes vsent de la raison ; XL. S'il est loisible de manger chair ; XLI. Que lon ne sçauroit viure ioyeusement selon Epicurus ; XLII. Si ce mot commun est bien dit, Cache ta vie ; XLIII. Les Regles & preceptes de Santé ; XLIV. De la Fortune des Romains ; XLV. De la Fortune ou vertu d'Alexandre ; XLVI. D'Isis & d'Osiris ; XLVII. Des Oracles qui ont cessé ; XLVIII. Que signifie ce mot Ei ; Indice très ample des noms, sentences et dits notables ; Address to reader. Simon Goulart ; Content.  ; I. Les Propos de Table ; II. Les Opinions des Philosophes ; III. Les Demandes des choses Romaines ; IV. Les Demandes des choses Grecques ; V. Collation abregee d'aucunes histoires ; VI. Les vies des dix Orateurs.  ; VII. De trois fortes de gouuernement ; VIII. Sommaire de la Comparaison d'Aristophanes & de Menander ; IX. Estranges Accidents aduenus pour l'Amour ; X. Quels Animaux sont les plus aduisez ; XI. Si les Atheniens ont esté plus excellents en armes qu'en lettres ; XII. Lequel est plus vtile, le feu, ou l'eau ; XIII. Du premier froid ; XIV. Les Causes naturelles ; XV. Les Questions Platoniques  ; XVI. De la creation de l'Ame ; XVII. De la fatale Destinee ; XVIII. Que les Stoïques disent des choses plus estranges que les Poëtes ; XIX. Les contredicts des Philosophes Stoïques  ; XX. Des communes Conceptions contre les Stoiques ; XXI. Contre l'Epicurien Colotes ; XXII. De l'Amour ; XXIII. De la face qui apparoist au rond de la Lune ; XXIV. Pourquoy la prophetisse Pythie ne rend plus les oracles en vers ; XXV. De l'Esprit familier de Socrates ; XXVI. De la malignité d'Herodote ; XXVII. De la Musique ; Indice

author: Plutarchus
Translator: Gandini, Marco Antonio ; Tarcagnota, Giovanni ; Massa, Antonio ; Grazi, Grazio Maria
Title: Opuscoli morali, di Plutarco Cheronese, filosofo, & historico notabilissimo. Divisi in due parti principali. Copiosi di necessarii precetti da essere essequiti da prencipi, da popoli, da sacerdoti, da laici, da figliuoli, da mariti, da mogli, da padroni,& da servi. Tradotti in volgare dal sign. Marc'Antonio Gandino, & da altri letterati. Con due tavole, una delli opuscoli, & l'altra delle cose piu notabili. Con due tavole, una delli opuscoli, et l'altra delle cose più notabili
Additional Notes: Inspected copy in HAB. On the verso of the title-page of vol. 1 it lists four translators 'che hanno tradotta questa Prima Parte delli Opuscoli di Plutarco', so it's clear that this is a collected volume, not a completely new translation. The volumes then indicate who has translated what on the contents page, omitting mention there of Massi.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Van het gheluck ende ongheluck des houwelicks
Additional Notes: Not seen. Not attributed to Plutarch in USTC. Aulotte, p. 64 n. 3 states that 1578 Antwerp edition includes the Plutarch translation and is based on Marconville's French and notes it's reprinted in Delft in 1601 and in Wormerveer in 1647. This is an earlier edition of the former (same title and length).

(my edition, p. 11)

author: Plutarchus
Other Authors: Wolf, Hieronymus ; Scaliger, Julius Caesar ; Melanchthon, Philipp ; Hayneccius, Martin ; Lucian ; Isocrates ; Agapetus ; Basil of Caesarea
Title: Ενχιριδιον ηθικον:|| COMPENDIVM || MORALIVM PRAE-||CEPTIONVM: || è || TRIPLICI VIRTVTVM || ac Officiorum genere: Pro Pueris || CONFECTVM:|| SED ET ADVLTIORIBVS || PROFVTVRVM; AD || Tria vitae genera;|| OECONOMICVM;|| SCHOLASTICVM;|| POLITICVM;|| Cum Argumentis, et Notis ... || PARTE auctum ALTERA.|| ... || RECENSVIT || Martinus Hayneccius.||
Contents: De liberis educandis ; Quomodo adolescens poetas audire debeat
Additional Notes: Inspected copy in HAB. USTC gives what is at best a misleading title. Not attributed to Plutarch in USTC or VD16 (http://gateway-bayern.de/VD16+H+866) but it is in HAB catalogue. Parallel text edition of the usual school edition (with Isocrates and Lucian, but in this case with Agapetus added). CHECK which Latin translation is used. This edition adds a second part (t-p: 'PARTE auctum ALTERA'), which has its own separate t-p and also includes How the Young Man Should Study Poetry alongside Basil's treatise on reading pagan authors.

author: Plutarchus
Title: La mesnagerie
Contents: Oeconomicus ; Coniugalia praecepta ; Consolatio ad uxorem
Additional Notes: Not seen but based on Aulotte. Aulotte notes that Con. Praec. (but not Cons. ad Ux.) is indebted to the Latin (of Carlo Valgulio) but is mainly translated from the Greek. Not included in data we got from USTC but now attributed to Plutarch in 1571 and 1572 but not 1600 edition, but it's clear from the signatures that Plutarch's treatises are included, and this is confirmed by Aulotte. USTC 34149 appears to be a ghost (look at the signatures).

Contents: De fato ; Sept. sap. conv. ; De prim. frig. ; De an. procr. ; De def. orac. ;

author: Plutarchus
Other Authors: Goulart, Simon ; Acciaiuoli, Donato ; Cornelius Nepos ; Aemilius Probus ; Cruser, Hermann
Title: The liues of the noble Grecians and Romaines, compared together by that graue learned philosopher and historiographer, Plutarke of Chæronea. Translated out of Greeke into French by Iames Amiot abbot of Bellozane, Bishop of Auxerre, one of the Kings priuie Counsell, and grea Amner of France. VVith the liues of Hannibal and of Scipio African: translated out of Latine into French by Charles de l’Escluse, and out of French into English, by Sir Thomas North Knight. Hereunto are also added the liues of Epaminondas, of Philip of Macedon, of Dionysius the elder, tyrant of Sicilia, of Augustus Cæsar, of Plutarke, and of Seneca: with the liues of nine other excellent chiefetaines of warre: collected out of Æmylius Probus, by S.G.S. and Englished by the aforesaid translator.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Les Oeuvres morales et meslées
Contents: VOL. 1 ; Dedication: Amyot to Charles IX ; Simon Goulart, Address to readers ; Contents ; I. Comment il fault nourrir les Enfans ; II. Comment il fault lire les Poëtes ; III. Comment il fault ouir ; IV. De la Vertu morale ; V. Du vice & de la vertu ; VI. Que la vertu se peult enseigner ; VII. Comment on pourra discerner le flatteur d'auec l'amy ; VIII. Comment il fault refrener la cholere ; IX. De la Curiosité ; X. De la Tranquillité de l'ame & repos de l'esprit ; XI. De la mauuaise honte ; XII. De l'amitié fraternelle ; XIII. Du trop parler ; XIV. De l'auarice & conuoitise d'auoir ; XV. De l'amour & charité naturelle des peres enuers les enfans ; XVI. De la pluralité d'amis ; XVII. De la Fortune ; XVIII. De l'enuie & de la haine ; XIX. Comment on pourra receuoir vtilité de ses ennemis ; XX. Comment on pourra apperceuoir si lon amende en l'exercice de la vertu ; XXI. De la superstition ; XXII. Du Bannissement ; XXIII. Qu'il ne fault point emprunter à vsure ; XXIV. Qu'il fault qu’vn Philosophe conuerse avec les Princes ; XXV. Qu'il est requis qu'vn Prince soit sçauant ; XXVI. Que le vice est suffisant pour rendre l'homme malheureux ; XXVII. Comment on se peult louer soy mesme sans reprehension ; XXVIII. Quelles passions sont les pires, celles de l'ame, ou celles du corps ; XXIX. Les Preceptes de Mariage ; XXX. Le Banquet des sept Sages ; XXXI. Instruction pour ceulx qui manient affaires d'estat ; XXXII. Si l'homme d'aage se doit mesler d'affaires publicques ; XXXIII. Les dicts notables des anciens Roys, Princes & grands Capitaines ; XXXIV. Les dicts notables des Lacedaemoniens ; XXXV. Les vertueux faicts des femmes ; XXXVI. Consolation enuoyee à Apollonius sur la mort de son fils ; XXXVII. Consolation enuoyee à sa femme, sur la mort de sa fille ; XXXVIII. Pourquoy la Iustice diuine differe quelque fois la punition des malefices ; XXXIX. Que les bestes brutes vsent de la raison ; XL. S'il est loisible de manger chair ; XLI. Que lon ne sçauroit viure ioyeusement selon Epicurus ; XLII. Si ce mot commun est bien dit, Cache ta vie ; XLIII. Les Regles & preceptes de Santé ; XLIV. De la Fortune des Romains ; XLV. De la Fortune ou vertu d'Alexandre ; XLVI. D'Isis & d'Osiris ; XLVII. Des Oracles qui ont cessé ; XLVIII. Que signifie ce mot Ei ; VOL. 2 ; Simon Goulart, Address to readers ; Contents  ; I. Les Propos de Table ; II. Les Opinions des Philosophes ; III. Les Demandes des choses Romaines ; IV. Les Demandes des choses Grecques ; V. Collation abregee d'aucunes histoires ; VI. Les vies des dix Orateurs.  ; VII. De trois fortes de gouuernement ; VIII. Sommaire de la Comparaison d'Aristophanes & de Menander ; IX. Estranges Accidents aduenus pour l'Amour ; X. Quels Animaux sont les plus aduisez ; XI. Si les Atheniens ont esté plus excellents en armes qu'en lettres ; XII. Lequel est plus vtile, le feu, ou l'eau ; XIII. Du premier froid ; XIV. Les Causes naturelles ; XV. Les Questions Platoniques  ; XVI. De la creation de l'Ame ; XVII. De la fatale Destinee ; XVIII. Que les Stoïques disent des choses plus estranges que les Poëtes ; XIX. Les contredicts des Philosophes Stoïques  ; XX. Des communes Conceptions contre les Stoiques ; XXI. Contre l'Epicurien Colotes ; XXII. De l'Amour ; XXIII. De la face qui apparoist au rond de la Lune ; XXIV. Pourquoy la prophetisse Pythie ne rend plus les oracles en vers ; XXV. De l'Esprit familier de Socrates ; XXVI. De la malignité d'Herodote ; XXVII. Additional Notes: Copy inspected in HAB. Not attributed to Plutarch in USTC. VD17 notes that there are two variants of this edition, with different title-pages: https://kxp.k10plus.de/DB=1.28/CMD?ACT=SRCHA&IKT=8079&TRM=%2723:275837X%27 and https://kxp.k10plus.de/DB=1.28/CMD?ACT=SRCHA&IKT=8079&TRM=%2712:639648P%27 . The title-page of the 1578 edition declares that the Plutarch treatises are translated from the Latin but I have inferred (not checked) that the translators were Carlo Valgulio and Guarino Veronese.

author: Plutarchus
Intermediary Translators: Jobin, Bernhard ; Erasmus, Desiderius ; Guevara, Antonio de ; Vay, Johann ; Carlo Valgulio ; Guarino Veronese
Other Authors: Jobin, Bernhard ; Erasmus, Desiderius ; Guevara, Antonio de ; Vay, Johann ; Carlo Valgulio ; Guarino Veronese
Title: Das Philosophisch Ehezuchtbüchlin oder Die Vernunfft gemäse Naturgescheide Ehezucht/ sampt der Kinderzucht : Auß des ... Plutarchi/ vernunfft gemäsen Ehegebotten/ unnd allerley andern Anmütigen Gleichnussen/ Sprichwörtern/ Gesängen/ Reimen der ... Authoren und Scribenten ... zusammen gelesen/ und verteutscht ... mit beygethaner Missiff und Ehelicher schuldigkeit Erinnerung Herrn Anthoni von Guevara / Durch ... Herrn Johann Fischarten genandt Mentzer ... auß Griechischen und andern Sprachen verteutscht/ und zusamen getragen
Additional Notes: Checked online copy. Not attributed to Plutarch in USTC, which has two records, apparently aggregated from different datasets. The title-page of the 1578 edition declares that the Plutarch treatises are translated from the Latin but I have inferred (not checked) that the translators were Carlo Valgulio and Guarino Veronese.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Les Oeuvres morales et meslées
Imprint: Lyon, chez Paul Frellon et Antoine de Harsy, 1615
Contents: VOL. 1 ; Dedication: Amyot to Charles IX ; Simon Goulart, Address to readers ; Contents ; I. Comment il fault nourrir les Enfans ; II. Comment il fault lire les Poëtes ; III. Comment il fault ouir ; IV. De la Vertu morale ; V. Du vice & de la vertu ; VI. Que la vertu se peult enseigner ; VII. Comment on pourra discerner le flatteur d'auec l'amy ; VIII. Comment il fault refrener la cholere ; IX. De la Curiosité ; X. De la Tranquillité de l'ame & repos de l'esprit ; XI. De la mauuaise honte ; XII. De l'amitié fraternelle ; XIII. Du trop parler ; XIV. De l'auarice & conuoitise d'auoir ; XV. De l'amour & charité naturelle des peres enuers les enfans ; XVI. De la pluralité d'amis ; XVII. De la Fortune ; XVIII. De l'enuie & de la haine ; XIX. Comment on pourra receuoir vtilité de ses ennemis ; XX. Comment on pourra apperceuoir si lon amende en l'exercice de la vertu ; XXI. De la superstition ; XXII. Du Bannissement ; XXIII. Qu'il ne fault point emprunter à vsure ; XXIV. Qu'il fault qu’vn Philosophe conuerse avec les Princes ; XXV. Qu'il est requis qu'vn Prince soit sçauant ; XXVI. Que le vice est suffisant pour rendre l'homme malheureux ; XXVII. Comment on se peult louer soy mesme sans reprehension ; XXVIII. Quelles passions sont les pires, celles de l'ame, ou celles du corps ; XXIX. Les Preceptes de Mariage ; XXX. Le Banquet des sept Sages ; XXXI. Instruction pour ceulx qui manient affaires d'estat ; XXXII. Si l'homme d'aage se doit mesler d'affaires publicques ; XXXIII. Les dicts notables des anciens Roys, Princes & grands Capitaines ; XXXIV. Les dicts notables des Lacedaemoniens ; XXXV. Les vertueux faicts des femmes ; XXXVI. Consolation enuoyee à Apollonius sur la mort de son fils ; XXXVII. Consolation enuoyee à sa femme, sur la mort de sa fille ; XXXVIII. Pourquoy la Iustice diuine differe quelque fois la punition des malefices ; XXXIX. Que les bestes brutes vsent de la raison ; XL. S'il est loisible de manger chair ; XLI. Que lon ne sçauroit viure ioyeusement selon Epicurus ; XLII. Si ce mot commun est bien dit, Cache ta vie ; XLIII. Les Regles & preceptes de Santé ; XLIV. De la Fortune des Romains ; XLV. De la Fortune ou vertu d'Alexandre ; XLVI. D'Isis & d'Osiris ; XLVII. Des Oracles qui ont cessé ; XLVIII. Que signifie ce mot Ei ; Index (‘tresample des noms, sentence, et dicts notables’) ; Index (‘Suplement du precedent indice’) ;  VOL. 2 ; Simon Goulart, Address to readers ; Contents  ; I. Les Propos de Table ; II. Les Opinions des Philosophes ; III. Les Demandes des choses Romaines ; IV. Les Demandes des choses Grecques ; V. Collation abregee d'aucunes histoires ; VI. Les vies des dix Orateurs.  ; VII. De trois fortes de gouuernement ; VIII. Sommaire de la Comparaison d'Aristophanes & de Menander ; IX. Estranges Accidents aduenus pour l'Amour ; X. Quels Animaux sont les plus aduisez ; XI. Si les Atheniens ont esté plus excellents en armes qu'en lettres ; XII. Lequel est plus vtile, le feu, ou l'eau ; XIII. Du premier froid ; XIV. Les Causes naturelles ; XV. Les Questions Platoniques  ; XVI. De la creation de l'Ame ; XVII. De la fatale Destinee ; XVIII. Que les Stoïques disent des choses plus estranges que les Poëtes ; XIX. Les contredicts des Philosophes Stoïques  ; XX. Des communes Conceptions contre les Stoiques ; XXI. Contre l'Epicurien Colotes ; XXII. De l'Amour ; XXIII. De la face qui apparoist au rond de la Lune ; XXIV. Pourquoy la prophetisse Pythie ne rend plus les oracles en vers ; XXV. De l'Esprit familier de Socrates ; XXVI. De la malignité d'Herodote ; XXVII. De la Musique ; Index (‘des principales matieres et choses’)
Additional Notes: Inspected both vols in HAB. Digital copy of vol. 1 alone. USTC includes 'Harsy, Antoine de (widow of)' as a printer, but there is no evidence of that in my copy, and I wasn't able to find this information in the BnF or BL catalogue, though it's possible a variant with this imprint exists.

author: Plutarchus
Title: Les oeuvres morales
Imprint: Lyon, chez Paul Frellon et Antoine de Harsy, 1615
Contents: VOL. 1 ; Dedication: Amyot to Charles IX ; Simon Goulart, Address to readers ; Contents ; I. Comment il fault nourrir les Enfans ; II. Comment il fault lire les Poëtes ; III. Comment il fault ouir ; IV. De la Vertu morale ; V. Du vice & de la vertu ; VI. Que la vertu se peult enseigner ; VII. Comment on pourra discerner le flatteur d'auec l'amy ; VIII. Comment il fault refrener la cholere ; IX. De la Curiosité ; X. De la Tranquillité de l'ame & repos de l'esprit ; XI. De la mauuaise honte ; XII. De l'amitié fraternelle ; XIII. Du trop parler ; XIV. De l'auarice & conuoitise d'auoir ; XV. De l'amour & charité naturelle des peres enuers les enfans ; XVI. De la pluralité d'amis ; XVII. De la Fortune ; XVIII. De l'enuie & de la haine ; XIX. Comment on pourra receuoir vtilité de ses ennemis ; XX. Comment on pourra apperceuoir si lon amende en l'exercice de la vertu ; XXI. De la superstition ; XXII. Du Bannissement ; XXIII. Qu'il ne fault point emprunter à vsure ; XXIV. Qu'il fault qu’vn Philosophe conuerse avec les Princes ; XXV. Qu'il est requis qu'vn Prince soit sçauant ; XXVI. Que le vice est suffisant pour rendre l'homme malheureux ; XXVII. Comment on se peult louer soy mesme sans reprehension ; XXVIII. Quelles passions sont les pires, celles de l'ame, ou celles du corps ; XXIX. Les Preceptes de Mariage ; XXX. Le Banquet des sept Sages ; XXXI. Instruction pour ceulx qui manient affaires d'estat ; XXXII. Si l'homme d'aage se doit mesler d'affaires publicques ; XXXIII. Les dicts notables des anciens Roys, Princes & grands Capitaines ; XXXIV. Les dicts notables des Lacedaemoniens ; XXXV. Les vertueux faicts des femmes ; XXXVI. Consolation enuoyee à Apollonius sur la mort de son fils ; XXXVII. Consolation enuoyee à sa femme, sur la mort de sa fille ; XXXVIII. Pourquoy la Iustice diuine differe quelque fois la punition des malefices ; XXXIX. Que les bestes brutes vsent de la raison ; XL. S'il est loisible de manger chair ; XLI. Que lon ne sçauroit viure ioyeusement selon Epicurus ; XLII. Si ce mot commun est bien dit, Cache ta vie ; XLIII. Les Regles & preceptes de Santé ; XLIV. De la Fortune des Romains ; XLV. De la Fortune ou vertu d'Alexandre ; XLVI. D'Isis & d'Osiris ; XLVII. Des Oracles qui ont cessé ; XLVIII. Que signifie ce mot Ei ; Index (‘tresample des noms, sentences, et dicts notables’) ; Index (‘Suplement du precedent indice’) ;  VOL. 2 ; Simon Goulart, Address to readers ; Contents  ; I. Les Propos de Table ; II. Les Opinions des Philosophes ; III. Les Demandes des choses Romaines ; IV. Les Demandes des choses Grecques ; V. Collation abregee d'aucunes histoires ; VI. Les vies des dix Orateurs.  ; VII. De trois fortes de gouuernement ; VIII. Sommaire de la Comparaison d'Aristophanes & de Menander ; IX. Estranges Accidents aduenus pour l'Amour ; X. Quels Animaux sont les plus aduisez ; XI. Si les Atheniens ont esté plus excellents en armes qu'en lettres ; XII. Lequel est plus vtile, le feu, ou l'eau ; XIII. Du premier froid ; XIV. Les Causes naturelles ; XV. Les Questions Platoniques  ; XVI. De la creation de l'Ame ; XVII. De la fatale Destinee ; XVIII. Que les Stoïques disent des choses plus estranges que les Poëtes ; XIX. Les contredicts des Philosophes Stoïques  ; XX. Des communes Conceptions contre les Stoiques ; XXI. Contre l'Epicurien Colotes ; XXII. De l'Amour ; XXIII. Aulotte, p. 64 n. 3 states that 1578 Antwerp edition includes the Plutarch translation and is based on Marconville's French and notes it's reprinted in Delft in 1601 and in Wormerveer in 1647. The reproduction of the title-page at http://resolver.kb.nl/resolve?urn=stcn:831203749:01 proves that this is correct. See also M. Boas, 'Nederlandsche vertalingen der Moralia van Plutarchus', Het Boek (1916), 5: 237-38.

Contents: Dedication. Amyot to Charles IX ; Content. Lists contents for all three vols. ; I. Comment il fault nourrir les Enfans ; II. Comment il fault lire les Poëtes ; III. Comment il fault refrener la cholere ; IX. De la Curiosité ; X. De la Tranquillité de l'ame & repos de l'esprit ; XI. De la mauuaise honte ; XII. De l'amitié fraternelle ; XIII. Du trop parler ; XIV. De l'auarice & conuoitise d'auoir ; XV. De l'amour & charité naturelle des peres enuers les enfans ; XVI. De la pluralité d'amis ; XVII. De la Fortune ; XVIII. De l'enuie & de la haine ; XIX. Comment on pourra receuoir vtilité de ses ennemis ; XX. Comment on pourra apperceuoir si lon amende en l'exercice de la vertu ; XXI. De la superstition ; XXII. Du Bannissement ; XXIII. Qu'il ne fault point emprunter à vsure ; XXIV. Qu'il fault qu’vn Philosophe conuerse avec les Princes ; XXV. Qu'il est requis qu'vn Prince soit sçauant ; XXVI. Que le vice est suffisant pour rendre l'homme malheureux ; XXVII. Comment on se peult louer soy mesme sans reprehension ; XXVIII. Instruction pour ceulx qui manient affaires d'estat ; XXXII. Si l'homme d'aage se doit mesler d'affaires publicques ; XXXIII. Pourquoy la Iustice diuine differe quelque fois la punition des malefices ; XXXIX. Que les bestes brutes vsent de la raison ; XL. S'il est loisible de manger chair ; XLI. De la Fortune ou vertu d'Alexandre ; XLVI. D'Isis & d'Osiris ; XLVII. Des Oracles qui ont cessé ; XLVIII. Que signifie ce mot Ei ; XLIX. Collation abregee d'aucunes histoires ; VI. Les vies des dix Orateurs.  ; VII. De trois fortes de gouuernement ; VIII. Sommaire de la Comparaison d'Aristophanes & de Menander ; IX. Estranges Accidents aduenus pour l'Amour ; X. Quels Animaux sont les plus aduisez ; XI. Si les Atheniens ont esté plus excellents en armes qu'en lettres ; XII. Lequel est plus vtile, le feu, ou l'eau ; XIII. Du premier froid ; XIV. Les Causes naturelles ; XV. Les Questions Platoniques  ; XVI. De la creation de l'Ame ; XVII. De la fatale Destinee ; XVIII. Que les Stoïques disent des choses plus estranges que les Poëtes ; XIX. Les contredicts des Philosophes Stoïques  ; XX. Des communes Conceptions contre les Stoiques ; XXI. Contre l'Epicurien Colotes ; XXII. De l'Amour ; XXIII. De la face qui apparoist au rond de la Lune ; XXIV. Pourquoy la prophetisse Pythie ne rend plus les oracles en vers ; XXV. Title: Opus cum interprete Oliuerio, & paucis annotationibus quas Arcadicus ille sub Theophili nomine marginibus inspersit. Id Antonius Lenas praeclarael indolis adolescens recognovit eo uidelicet consilio ut per eam occasionem bicipitis illius monstri latratus & plusquam cerbeream rabiem coerceret sed preceptoris modestias obtemperans ab incepto destitit gratuita te uindictae praesentem levitatem compensaturus.
